Park Ave. and 41st St.
1870
Photo by Brown Brothers
220 West 42nd St.
New York City

park Ave., east side, south from 41st Street, during the construction of the Lexington Ave. Subway. The 41st Street pedestrian overpass has been temporarily taken down. On the right, appears a portion of the Murray Hill Hotel.

April 5, 1901.

Grand Union Hotel, Park Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets, also showing the new Grand Central Station and the old spur of the Third Avenue Elevated, which will be taken down in 1924.

The Grand Union was to a great extent built by acquisition of old houses in the block, intervening walls being knocked out and rooms remodelled. The whole is shown shortly before demolition. Compare this with later pictures of the same block.

1914.

Gift of E.M. Jenks.

Pershing Square (Park Avenue), east side, from East 41st (right) to 42nd (left), Street's, showing the Grand Union Hotel of the 1890's. This structure was demolished in the Summer of 1914, and was later replaced with the present Pershing Square Building. The 40th-42nd Street area acquired this designation in honor of the Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in France about this time. It was originally Fourth Avenue, a section of which was changed to Park Avenue.

About 1914

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)

text:
Pershing Square (Park Avenue), east side, from East 41st (right) to 42nd (left) Street's, showing the Grand Union Hotel of the 1890's. This structure was removed in the Summer of 1914. Upon this site was erected the Pershing Square Building. Note the Architects Building on the right margin; the absence of the automobile viaduct over the Avenue; and the old "El" spur on 42nd Street.

About 1914

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)

text: Park Avenue, west side, from 41st to 42nd Streets, the side entrance to the Hotel Belmont, at Pershing Square. Probably late 1918.

Park Avenue, 41st to 42nd Streets (the future Pershing Square), showing construction of viaduct for automobile traffic over the old northern entrance to the Murray Hill tunnel and around the western shoulder of the new Grand Central Station. Work on this project was commenced November 2, 1917. The Hotel Commodore, as shown here, is quite new.

On the east side of Park Avenue, from 41st to 42nd Streets, the old Grand Union Hotel stood until its demolition in 1914; the southern end of the new East Side express station of the new subway, nearly ready to open, lies underneath. The old elevated station, originally only one end of a short shuttle, will stand here till 1924. Compare this with 1914, 1920, 1923, and later pictures.

Early 1918.

Brown Brothers.

Park Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets, on Pershing Square, where the Grand Union Hotel stood until June, 1914, showing the new Grand Central Station and the recently completed Hotel Commodore on the north side of 42nd Street, also the old elevated spur used until 1923 as a shuttle to the Third Avenue line. The covered stairways in the vacant lot are entrances to the express station of the new east side Interborough Subway, which was opened in the summer of 1918. About 1919.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Pershing Square, Park Avenue from 41st to 42nd Streets, looking west at the Hotel Belmont (1906-31) from the vacant lot where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand and where the Pershing Square building will be erected. The name Pershing Square, after General Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force, was applied to this block about the time of the Armistice.

The Pershing Square viaduct, shown here, conducted automobile traffic from Park Avenue and 40th Street across 42nd Street and around the left side of the Grand Central Station to Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street. As shown here it is quite new. The covered stairway coming up out of the vacant lot in the foreground is an entrance to the new Lexington Avenue Interborough Subway, opened in the summer of 1918.

On the S.W. corner of 41st Street may be seen part of the old Murray Hill Hotel; and west on 42nd Street the Hotel Manhattan on the N. W. corner of Madison Avenue, later to be remodelled into an office building and uptown office for the National City Bank. The small building on the N. E. corner of Madison Avenue and 42nd Street is shortly to be demolished and replaced by the Liggett Drug building.

About 1920.

Gift of E.M. Jenks.

Excavation and shoring for the Pershing Square Building, Park Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets.

June 26, 1922.

Irving Underhill.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Excavation for the Pershing Square Building, Park Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets. The Grand Central Station is at the extreme left. At the right is the Hotel Commodore. In front of the two is the Park Avenue station of the 42nd Street spur of the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad. This spur will be demolished within two years.

June 26, 1922.

Irving Underhill.
Gift of York & Sawyer.

Pershing Square, Park Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 41st Streets, showing the newly completed Pershing Square Building on the site of the old Grand Union Hotel, the new Bowery Savings Bank to the left at 110 East 42nd Street and the Pershing Square Viaduct and Third Avenue Elevated station in the foreground.
The old Grand Union, shown in a 1914 picture of this block, was shortly thereafter pulled down, while the new Lexington Avenue subway station and the junction with the old line were constructed under Park Avenue in this block. Then about the time of the Armistice this block was named Pershing Square, after General John J. Pershing, and the automobile viaduct built to conduct traffic from 40th Street and Park Avenue over 41st and 42nd Streets and around on the west side of the Grand Central Station to Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street. When the New York Central building is built in 1928 traffic will be divided at the point shown here, and a double viaduct built through to 46th Street and Park Avenue.
The Elevated spur shown here was originally a temporary terminal of the Third Avenue line, but for many years has served as a shuttle from the Grand Central Station to the main Elevated line at Third Avenue and 42nd Street. It is about to be demolished, at the time of this picture.
On the S.E. corner of 42nd Street is 103 Park Avenue, an office building built about 1900, and beyond it may be seen part of the newer Architects' Building (1916)
1923.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

41st Street, south side, at Park Avenue, view east, showing 56 and 58 East 41st Street and the northern side of the Murray Hill Hotel.

September 5, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Pershing Square (Park Ave.), west side, from East 41st (left) to 42nd (right) Streets, showing the Belmont Hotel. This building, erected about 1906, was demolished in 1931. The site, today (1937) is still vacant.

Prior to 1931.

International News Photos.
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)

text:
(1) Pershing Square, (Park Ave.) west side, from East 42nd to 41st Streets. Also shown is the Murray Hill Hotel, at No. 112 Park Ave., west side, from East 41st to 40th Streets. Building shown under demolition is the Hotel Belmont. This view is as seen from the Graybar Building and across Grand Central Station; southward. Note the raised vehicular vi- duct at this point.

April 28, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing mainly the Hotel Belmont.

April 28, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another view, similar to No. 2.

April 28, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street

text:
Pershing Square, at the N.E. corner of East 41st Street, as seen viewing eastward on 41st Street, from a point just west of the west side of the Square. Building shown, is the Pershing Square Building. Across its roof appears portions of the Chanin and Chrysler Buildings. Note the Vehicular viaduct at this point.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
